1-2 Ukrainian Neptune cruise missiles have impacted the T-25 110/35/6 kV electrical substation in the city of Taganrog, Rostov Oblast. A large fire can be seen burning there, and disruptions in power, communication and water supply is reported. 
Coordinates: 47.21244, 38.87464

1-2 Ukrainian Neptune cruise missiles have impacted the T-25 110/35/6 kV electrical substation in the city of Taganrog, Rostov Oblast. A large fire can be seen burning there, and disruptions in power, communication and water supply is reported.

Russian forces have captured the village of Rybne, Hulyaipole direction, Zaporizhzhia Oblast.
Pre-war population: ~50.
Total land area: ~0.62 km¬≤.

While everyone focuses on Pokrovsk, the situation in the Hulyaipole direction continues to deteriorate even further for Ukraine. 
Russia is advancing to new areas while facing minimal resistance and is now approaching the rear of Hulyaipole itself.

Regarding the Myrnohrad pocket, I think a lot of people are significantly overestimating the number of Ukrainian soldiers encircled there.
Myrnohrad is a big city, and when you include its surroundings there are a lot of other positions to hold. But Ukraine has become increasingly reliant on drones, often spreading infantry very thin across lines, creating a disorganised and often incoherent ground defence. Myrnohrad is an example of this, and there are a lot of nearby settlements that are good for concentrations of drone operators. 
Additionally, many Ukrainian soldiers actually escaped this pocket back when it was still a salient. This is what allowed for Russia to penetrate deeper into the northern and southern parts of the city. 
For an area of its size, with a significantly reduced garrison, I estimate that there are anywhere between 300 and 700 Ukrainian soldiers currently trapped there. It's impossible to know how many right now, but with the state the war is in today and other patterns observed from this front, it will be less than many people expect.

A short time ago, two Russian MiG-31Ks departed from Savasleika Airbase, Nizhny Novgorod Oblast, and launched two Kinzhal hypersonic aeroballistic missiles at Starokostyantyniv Airbase in Khmelnytskyi Oblast.
Both missiles impacted the airbase. Starkostyantyniv is known to house Su-24 tactical bombers which are used for glide-bomb strikes on frontline areas as well as storm shadow cruise missiles strikes, and has the capability to house F-16s and Mirage-2000 fighters.  
Interestingly, the MiG-31Ks used the new launch lines in southwestern Ryazan Oblast again. This is the second recorded instance of this taking place, with the first happening during the attacks on Ozerne Airbase, Zhytomyr Oblast a week ago on November 3.

Ukrainian sea drones are once again attacking the Tuapse Port in Krasnodar Krai. One impact has been recorded at Pier 167.
Coordinates: 44.100401, 39.058302

Ukrainian sea drones are once again attacking the Tuapse Port in Krasnodar Krai. One impact has been recorded at Pier 167.
Coordinates: 44.100401, 39.058302

It turns out that the target of the Ukrainian HIMARS attack on Donetsk yesterday was a complex of storage warehouses for Russian Geran-2 drones at Donetsk International Airport. FP-2 drones were also used, which are seen striking the warehouses in this video.‚Ä¶

Satellite imagery shows that as a result of the combined Ukrainian FP-2 drone and HIMARS GMLRS strike on Donetsk International Airport, only two smaller warehouses storing Geran-2 drones were hit. 
One warehouse was completely destroyed, while the other received significant damage. The number of drones destroyed is probably less than 100. It's likely that the FP-2 drones only targeted these two warehouses, while the HIMARS mainly targeted the other warehouses and were mostly shot down.
Image credit
The first snow has begun falling in Slovyansk, Donetsk Oblast.

Around six Russian Geran-2 drones impacted the town of Orilka, Kharkiv Oblast, this evening. 
They were likely targeting the railway station as it is placed along the railway line to the major logistical hub of Barvinkove, Kharkiv Oblast. Barvinkove is used to resupply practically all of Ukrainian-controlled Donetsk Oblast, as well as parts of frontline Kharkiv Oblast.

SYRIA:  ‚Äî Footage has surfaced online of Russian military vehicles moving across the Rastan Bridge toward Homs for the first time since the overthrow of Bashar al-Assad.
Earlier, the new authorities in Damascus announced they are ready to sign a security agreement with Moscow.

The first footage has been published showing the British-developed "Raven" air defence system being used by Ukraine. The video shows it intercepting a Russian Kh-59 cruise missile, as well as a Kh-101 cruise missile.
The "Raven" system integrates AIM-132 advanced short-range air-to-air missiles with a 6x6 high-mobility armoured truck, allowing for more rapid deployments and effective interception rates, especially during larger-scale attacks.

Footage showing a Russian FAB-3000 glide-bomb strike on a concentration of Ukrainian infantry in the besieged city of Myrnohrad. 
Russia launches hundreds of glide-bombs per day. Many killed from the strikes will only ever be counted as MIA.

The West‚Äôs Goal Of "Displacing Russian Gas For Good": At What Price For Europe?
Europe‚Äôs leaders claim Russian gas can be phased out ‚Äúfor good,‚Äù but P-TEC exposes the real cost of this strategy. LNG dependency, US influence, and rising energy bills risk undermining Europe‚Äôs economy. A geopolitical shift may enhance Europe‚Äôs dependence.
The Sixth Partnership for Transatlantic Energy Cooperation¬†(P-TEC) took place last week in Athens, with Washington and its European partners once again vowing to ‚Äúdisplace Russian gas for good‚Äù.
This is a narrative that has dominated Western policymaking since 2022.¬†The question is whether this is truly feasible, or merely a political slogan attached to a costly long-term energy gamble.¬†One may recall that Europe once prided itself on ‚Äúenergy pragmatism,‚Äù particularly¬†Germany, whose industrial model relied on competitively priced Russian pipeline gas.

Ukraine Loses Two More Towns As Collapse Accelerates In Zaporizhzhia 
On November 10, the Russian military captured two more settlements in Zaporizhzhia amid accelerating Ukrainian collapse between the Yanchur River line and the city of Huliapole.
The two settlements, Sladkoe and Novoe, were captured by the 127th Motorized Rifle Division of the Vostok [East] Group of Forces, according to the Russian Ministry of Defense, which said in a statement that a total of 25 square kilometers were secured during operations there.
‚ÄúThe enemy suffered significant losses in personnel, equipment, and weapons, leaving armored vehicles, small arms, and ammunition in the [abandoned] positions,‚Äù it added.
Sladkoe and Novoe are located to the west of the Yanchur, nearly all of which is now under the control of the Vostok Group of Forces. Just a day earlier, the group captured Rybne, located right to the north of Sladkoe along the river.
üëâ

Russian Army Captures Hnativka After Neutralizing 200 Ukrainian Troops In Pokrovsk 
On November 10, the Russian military captured a small settlement adjacent to the key city of Pokrovsk in Donetsk after inflicting heavy losses on Ukrainian troops trapped there.
In a statement, the Russian Ministry of Defense said that the 2nd Combined Arms Army of the Tsentr [Center] Group of Forces captured Hnativka, located right to the east of Pokrovsk.
It added, that Russian troops expanded their control in the city itself, advancing in the ‚ÄúDinas‚Äù neighborhood, in the northwestern and eastern quarters of the Central district, as well as in the western industrial zone, and liberated 244 buildings within a day.

Syria Under Israeli Rule
The beginning of November 2025 marked a significant event in Syria: Trump decided to lift sanctions "at the request of Turkey and Israel." Thus, all the conclusions and analyses of experts who claimed that Assad's overthrow was in the interests of the Zionists were once again confirmed.
But of course, no one will talk about this. Moreover, a PR campaign has been launched in the global media to whitewash the Tahrir al-Sham regime, which is now being presented as a "fighter against ISIS." The jihadists in Damascus took the signal and staged a show of allegedly arresting ISIS supporters in areas of Syria under their control.
This entire absurdity is designed to improve the image of the "former" branch of Syrian al-Qaeda in the eyes of the international community, which is alarming moderate Ash'ari Sunnis, Druze, and Alawites. Because they are the ones targeted by the Damascus jihadists under the guise of "fighting terrorism."

Military Situation In Northern Palestine On November 10, 2025 (Map Update)

Israel Is Pushing Lebanese Army Into Confrontation With Hezbollah
Another wave of deadly strikes targeted Lebanon on November 10 amid reports suggesting that Israel was pushing the Lebanese military into a confrontation with Hezbollah.
Most of the strikes targeted southern Lebanon and the Beqaa Valley, with the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) later announcing that its struck sites used by Hezbollah for rocket launches and the production and storage of strategic weapons.
In a statement, the IDF said that the strikes, guided by the Military Intelligence Directorate and carried out with the air force under the Northern Command, were aimed at neutralizing weapons directed at Israel and preventing Hezbollah from rebuilding its ‚Äúterror infrastructure.‚Äù

Military Situation In Ukraine On November 10, 2025 (Maps Update)
Military Situation In Ukraine On November 10, 2025 (Maps Update)

Russian-Ukrainian Exchange Of Strikes: Kyiv Braces For Its Toughest Winter
On November 9-10, Russia and Ukraine continued their mutual strikes. According to the Russian Ministry of Defense, Russian air defense systems destroyed 71 Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles. The Ukrainian Air Force reported that overnight Russia used two Kinzhal hypersonic missile systems, five S-300/400 missiles, and 67 attack UAVs against Ukrainian territory, of which 52 drones were shot down.
Power outages in Ukraine this winter will be more extensive than in previous winter seasons, Ukrainian media report, citing a representative from a state-owned energy sector company.
"There is no frost yet, and there is already a shortage of power generation. In the future, it will only become more difficult. If we survive the winter with only two stages of blackouts, it will be a huge success. The energy system lost at least 1 gigawatt of generating capacity just from the latest attack," the message states.
üëâ
